• Lives saved vs. lives lost: you trade one death for five, a net reduction of harm.  
• Moral responsibility: by acting, you prevent greater suffering.  

Counter-points (deontological perspective):  
• You’re actively causing a death you wouldn’t have if you did nothing.  
• Some argue it’s wrong to use someone merely as a means, even to save more lives.  

Most ethicists conclude that, all things considered, diverting the trolley is the lesser evil.

Diverting the trolley would actively kill the one living person on the side track, with no greater good achieved. output: Assuming the isotope’s half‐life is one day, the chance it decays (and thus kills the cat) in 24 h is 50 %.  Hence the chance the cat is still alive when you open the box is also 50 %.
In the usual set‐up (one radioactive nucleus with a 50 % chance to decay in the allotted time) the cat ends up alive with probability ½, i.e. 50 %.

Assuming the isotope has a 50 % chance to decay in that one‐day interval (i.e. its half‐life is one day), then:

• The quantum state evolves into the superposition  
 (1/√2) (|undecayed⟩ ⊗ |alive cat⟩ + |decayed⟩ ⊗ |dead cat⟩).  
• Upon opening (measurement), each branch has probability |1/√2|²=½.  

So there is a 50 % chance you’ll find the cat alive (and 50 % dead).

results.prompt: A farmer is on one side of a river with a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. When he is crossing the river in a boat, he can only take one item with him at a time. Here’s one way (F=farmer, W=wolf, G=goat, C=cabbage; Left→Right is the boat crossing):

1. F takes G over.  
   Left: W + C Right: G  
2. F returns alone.  
   Left: W + C Right: G  
3. F takes W over.  
   Left: C Right: G + W  
4. F brings G back.  
   Left: G + C Right: W  
5. F takes C over.  
   Left: G Right: W + C  
6. F returns alone.  
   Left: G Right: W + C  
7. F takes G over.  
   Left: – Right: W + G + C  

At no point are G and W or G and C left alone together, so nothing gets eaten.

results.prompt: You're on a game show and are presented with three doors. Behind one is a donkey, and behind the other two are luxury cars. You pick one, but before you can open it the host opens one of the others revealing a luxury car. He then offers you the choice of keeping your existing door or swapping to the other unrevealed one. What should you do to win a car?
output:
You should keep your original pick.  Here’s why:

 1. On your first choice you have a 2∕3 chance of having picked a car (and a 1∕3 chance of having picked the donkey).  
 2. The host then must open one of the remaining doors that has a car behind it.  
  – If you’d initially picked the donkey (1∕3 chance), the two unopened doors both have cars, so the host opens one of them and switching wins you a car.  
  – If you’d initially picked a car (2∕3 chance), the other car is the one the host opens, leaving the donkey behind the remaining door—so switching loses.  
   
So  
• Staying wins whenever you were right at the start (2∕3).  
• Switching wins only when you were wrong at the start (1∕3).  

→ To maximize your chance of walking away with a car, stick with your original door (winning probability 2∕3).

You should keep your original pick.  Here’s why:

 1. Before any doors are opened you have a 2/3 chance of having picked a car, and only a 1/3 chance of having picked the donkey.  
 2. The host then opens one of the *other* two doors – but he is *forced* to open a door with a car behind it (there is always at least one car among the other two).  
 3. If your original choice was a car (probability 2/3) then the only remaining unopened door must be the donkey.  If your original choice was the donkey (probability 1/3) then the remaining unopened door is a car.  
 4. Thus  
    – Staying wins whenever you initially picked a car: 2/3 total chance.  
    – Switching wins only when you initially picked the donkey: 1/3 total chance.  

So to maximize your odds of driving away in a car, **do not swap** – stick with your first choice.

results.prompt: In a room of 30 people, what's the probability that at least two do not share a birthday?
output:
The easiest way is to use the “complement‐rule’’.  Let A be the event “at least two people share a birthday’’ in a group of 30; then

  P(no two share) = (365 ⋅ 364 ⋅ 363 ⋯ (365−29))∕365³⁰
                 = 365! ∕( (365−30)! · 365³⁰ )

so

  P(at least one shared birthday)
   = 1 − P(no two share)
   = 1 −  (365·364·…·336) / 365³⁰
   ≈ 1 − 0.2937
   ≈ 0.7063.

Numerically, about a 70.6% chance that in a room of 30 people at least two share a birthday.

Assume birthdays are iid uniform on 365 days (ignore leap‐years).

1.  Literal reading (“at least two people do not share a birthday” ⇔ “not everybody has the same birthday”):
   •  The only way everyone shares the same birthday is: pick one day (365 choices) and have all 30 born that day.  
   •  P(all 30 on the same day) = 365·(1/365)^30 = 1/365^29  
   ⇒  P(at least two have different birthdays) = 1 – 1/365^29 ≈ 1 – 10^(–76) ≃ 1.  

2.  (More likely what was intended) “at least two share a birthday” (the classic birthday paradox):
   •  P(all birthdays distinct) = (365/365)·(364/365)·…·(365–29)/365  
                      = 365! / ((365–30)!·365^30)  
   •  P(at least one shared birthday) = 1 – P(all distinct)  
                      = 1 – (365·364·…·336) / 365^30  
                      ≃ 0.7063  

So:  
– If you really meant “at least two do not share” (i.e. not all the same) the probability is 1 – 1/365^29 (essentially 1).  
– If you meant the usual “at least two *do* share” a birthday, it’s  
      1 – (365·364·…·336)/365^30 ≈ 0.7063.

Interpreting the question in the usual “birthday‐paradox” sense – i.e. “what is the probability that at least two people in a room of 30 share the same birthday?” – one computes

  P(no two share) = (365/365)·(364/365)·(363/365)·…·(336/365)
               = ∏_{k=0}^{29} (365 − k)/365

so

  P(at least one shared birthday)
    = 1 − P(no two share)
    = 1 − ∏_{k=0}^{29} (365 − k)/365
    ≈ 1 − 0.2937
    ≈ 0.7063

or about a 70.6% chance.

---

If you meant the literal reading “at least two do ​not​ share a birthday” (i.e. “not everyone has the very same birthday”), that probability is

  1 − P(all 30 born on the same day)
  = 1 − (1/365)^(29)
  ≈ 1 − 3.5×10^(-74)
  ≈ 1.0000 (for all practical purposes).

results.prompt: You have two ropes, each of which takes exactly 60 minutes to burn completely. However, the ropes burn unevenly, meaning some parts may burn faster or slower than others. You have no other timing device. How can you measure exactly 20 minutes using these two ropes and matches to light them?
output:
It turns out there is no way to get a 20-minute interval out of just two 60-minute “mystery” ropes if all you can do is light ends and wait for them to burn out.  With uneven burn‐rates the only burn-out times you can force (by lighting one end or both ends at once, or by re-lighting an end the moment the other rope dies) are

 • 60 min  (one end lit)  
 • 30 min  (both ends lit simultaneously)  
 • 45 min  (start one rope two-ended at t=0 and the other one-ended; when the two-ended rope dies at 30 min light the far end of the one-ended rope → it finishes at 30 + 15)  

and differences between those (15 min, 30 min, 45 min).  None of those is 20 min, so you simply cannot carve out exactly a 20 min span with only two such ropes and matches.

It turns out you can’t.  With only two “uneven” 60-minute fuses the only exact burn‐out events you can ever get are at 30 min (a rope lit at both ends), 60 min (one end), or combinations thereof (30+15=45 min, etc.).  No sequence of lightings will ever produce a finish at exactly 20 minutes, so there is simply no way to time out a 20-minute interval with only those two ropes.

There is no way to get a faithful “20 minute” mark out of two 60 minute ropes that burn at unknown rates.  With uneven‐burn ropes the only intervals you can carve off exactly are

 • 60 min   (burn one rope from one end)  
 • 30 min   (burn one rope from both ends)  
 • 15 min   (burn one rope from one end, then when you have another 30 min mark, light the other end and you get 15 more)  

and by chaining those you can get 45 min (30+15) or 60 min, but you can never isolate a 20 min span.  In particular there is no sequence of “light this rope end, then that rope end when X burns out” that will give you exactly 20 minutes.

results.prompt: You have two ropes, each of which takes exactly 60 minutes to burn completely. However, the ropes burn unevenly, meaning some parts may burn faster or slower than others. You have no other timing device. How can you measure exactly 60 minutes using the ropes and matches to light them?
output:
A very simple way to get a 60-minute interval out of two 60-minute ropes is to use each rope as a 30-minute timer, one after the other:

1. At t = 0 light Rope A at both ends.  Because it burns from both ends, it will be completely gone in 30 minutes (60 min total burn time ÷ 2).  
2. As soon as Rope A goes out (t = 30 min), light Rope B at both ends.  That, too, will now burn in exactly 30 minutes.  
3. When Rope B finally goes out, another 30 minutes have elapsed, making 60 minutes in all.

Even though the ropes burn unevenly, burning from both ends always halves the total burn time. By doing two back‐to‐back “both‐ends” burns you get exactly one hour.

One of the ropes can be used to “mark” the first 30 minutes, the other the second 30 minutes:

1. At time 0 light Rope A at both ends.  Because it burns from both ends, it will take exactly 30 minutes to burn completely (uneven burn‐rate doesn’t matter – two fronts always meet in half the total time).  
2. As soon as Rope A goes out you know 30 minutes have elapsed.  Immediately light Rope B at both ends.  
3. Rope B, now burning from both ends, will take another 30 minutes to burn out.  When it does, exactly 60 minutes will have passed in total.

Here’s the neatest way to get exactly one hour out of two “60-minute’’ ropes whose burn-rate is totally unpredictable:

1. Tie the two ropes together end‐to‐end so you now have one long rope whose total burn‐time (if lit at one end) is 60 + 60 = 120 minutes.  
2. Light both free ends of this long rope simultaneously.  

No matter how erratically the rope burns, when you set both ends alight the two flames will meet after exactly half the total burn‐time.   Since 120 minutes÷2 = 60 minutes, the instant the last bit of rope goes out is exactly one hour from when you first struck your match.

results.prompt: Imagine you're on a game show, and there are three doors in front of you. Behind one door is a car, and behind the other two doors are goats. You don't know what's behind any of the doors. You get to choose one door. Let's say you pick Door #1. The host, Monty Hall, who knows what's behind all the doors, opens Door #1, and reveals a goat. Now, you have two doors left: Door #3 and Door #2. You pick Door #3. Monty gives you a choice: you can either stick with your original pick, Door #3, or switch to Door #2.
output:
Once Monty is allowed to open your very first pick (so long as it’s a goat), all the “2‐for‐1” advantage of the classic Monty Hall set‐up disappears.  In fact if he simply picks a random goat door to open (even if it happens to be the one you chose) then the two remaining closed doors are equally likely to hide the car.

A quick Bayes‐style sketch:

  1. You start with P(car in #1)=P(car in #2)=P(car in #3)=1/3.
  2. Monty will open a goat door, picking uniformly at random among the goats.  
     – If your original pick (#1) was the car (prob 1/3), Monty can only open one of the other two goats (each with prob 1/2).  
     – If your original pick was a goat (prob 2/3), Monty has a 1/2 chance of opening that very goat (#1).  
  3. We observe “Monty opened #1 and it was a goat.”  
     –  P(Monty opens #1 | car in #1) = 0  
     –  P(Monty opens #1 | car in #2) = (1/3)·(1/2) = 1/6  
     –  P(Monty opens #1 | car in #3) = (1/3)·(1/2) = 1/6  
     ⇒  After normalization, P(car in #2 | opened #1)=½,  P(car in #3 | opened #1)=½.

No matter which of the two you now pick (and then stick with or switch to), your chance of finding the car is exactly 50%.  Switching gives you no advantage here.

Once Monty opens your very first choice (Door #1) and shows it’s a goat, all he’s done is eliminate that door.  He didn’t “save” the car for one of the remaining doors – he simply got rid of a goat you’d already picked.  So at that point Doors #2 and #3 are on equal footing.

  – P(car behind #2 | you saw a goat behind #1) = ½  
  – P(car behind #3 | you saw a goat behind #1) = ½  

Whether you stick with Door #3 or switch to Door #2, your chance of winning is exactly 50%.  There is no advantage either way.

Once Monty opens your very first pick (Door #1) and it turns out to be a goat, you know for a fact you didn’t pick the car on that initial 1/3‐chance choice.  You’re left with two unopened doors (2 and 3), behind one of which is the car—but Monty has not given you any further “biased” information about those two.  Thus the car is equally likely (½–½) to be behind Door 2 or Door 3.

So at this point:

• Sticking with Door 3 wins with probability ½.  
• Switching to Door 2 wins with probability ½.

There’s no longer a 2/3 vs. 1/3 advantage—once Monty opened your original pick, the remaining two doors split the probability evenly. You can switch or stay; your chance is 50%.

results.prompt: Imagine there's a small town with a very particular barber. This barber has a unique rule: he shaves all the men in town who visit him. Does the barber shave himself?
output:
There’s actually no paradox in the way you’ve stated it.  The barber’s rule is:

  •  “He shaves every man in town who comes to him for a shave.”

So whether he shaves himself comes down to one simple question: Does he ever go to the barber’s chair as a customer?  

  –  If he does, then by his own rule he shaves himself.  
  –  If he doesn’t, then by his rule he does not shave himself.  

There is nothing self‐contradictory here – he can simply choose to “visit” his own shop when he wants a shave (and thus shave himself) or not.  The famous Russell “barber paradox” only arises if the rule is instead:

  “The barber shaves exactly those men in town who do *not* shave themselves.”

In that version there is no consistent answer; but with “all who *do* visit him” it’s perfectly well-defined.

This turns out not to be a paradox at all but merely a one‐way rule:

  • Rule: “If a man in town visits the barber, the barber shaves him.”  
  • There is no statement about what happens if a man does ​not​ visit the barber.  

So for the barber himself, it’s simple:

  – If he ever “visits” his own shop as a customer, then by the rule he must shave himself.  
  – If he never visits, then he never shaves himself (at least not there).

There is no self–contradiction unless you add the extra clause “and only those men who do not shave themselves.”  As stated, he shaves himself exactly when (and only when) he treats himself as a client.

This is just a (slightly mis-stated) version of Russell’s barber paradox.  As given, the barber “shaves every man in town who visits him” and nobody else.  So:

•  If he never goes to his own shop, then by the rule he does not shave himself.  
•  If he does go to his own shop, then by the rule he does shave himself.  

The statement says nothing about whether the barber actually visits himself, so you cannot determine from the premises whether he shaves himself.  (If, on the other hand, the intended rule had been “he shaves all and only those men who do not shave themselves,” the very definition would be contradictory and no such barber could exist.)

His backward‐induction argument is self‐undermining: it assumes that if he survives to Thursday night he’ll then know the hanging must be Friday, but that very assumption depends on trusting the whole surprise‐criterion, which collapses once you try to pin down a last possible day. results.prompt: You are locked in a dungeon. A king decides to show you mercy - he summons you and tells you the rules: 'There are three doors, guarded by a guard that always tells the truth. Two of the doors lead to death. One door leads to escape.' You pick a door. The guard opens another door with certain death. You may change your door. How do you maximize your chances of escape?
output:
You should always switch to the one remaining closed door.  

Reasoning (the “Monty Hall” effect):  
1. Your first pick has a 1∕3 chance of being the escape door.  
2. The guard then deliberately opens a losing door among the other two.  
3. If your original choice was wrong (2∕3 chance), the one unopened door must be the escape.  
4. By switching, you win whenever your first pick was wrong—that is, with probability 2∕3.  
5. If you stay, you win only if your first pick was right—1∕3 chance.  

So to maximize your chance (2∕3 vs. 1∕3), switch.

You maximize your chance (2/3 vs. 1/3) by always switching.  

Reasoning (the Monty Hall argument):  
1. Your first pick has a 1/3 chance of being the escape door.  
2. The guard (who knows where death lies) then opens one of the two unpicked doors and always reveals death.  
3. The probability that the escape was in your originally chosen door remains 1/3, so the probability it’s in the one remaining closed door is 2/3.  
4. By switching, you win with probability 2/3; by staying, only 1/3.  

Therefore: pick a door, let the guard open a death‐door, then switch.

You should always switch to the other unopened door. 

Reason:  
- Your initial pick has a 1∕3 chance of being the escape door.  
- The two unpicked doors together therefore have a 2∕3 chance of hiding the escape.  
- The guard (who always tells the truth) then opens one of those two, revealing death, without touching the escape.  
- That entire 2∕3 probability now “collapses” onto the one remaining closed door.  

So by switching you win with probability 2∕3, instead of 1∕3 if you stay.

3) C and D cross together. Time += 10   (Left {A}; Right {B,C,D})  
4) B returns with the torch. Time += 3        (Left {A,B}; Right {C,D})  
5) A and B cross together again. Time += 3   (Left ∅; Right {A,B,C,D})  

Total = 3 + 1 + 10 + 3 + 3 = 20 minutes.

If you still want to hit 17 minutes, the only way is to change the 3-minute guy into a 2-minute guy.  Then the very same sequence  
(A + B cross, A returns; C + D cross, B returns; A + B cross)  
takes 2 + 1 + 10 + 2 + 2 = 17 minutes.

It turns out that with the speeds 1, 3, 5 and 10 the very best you can do is 20 minutes – you cannot get them all across in only 17 minutes.  For example, here is an optimal 20-minute schedule:

 2) A returns       →  1 min   (total 4)  
 3) C and D cross   → 10 min   (total 14)  
 4) B returns       →  3 min   (total 17)  
 5) A and B cross   →  3 min   (total 20)  

No other sequence can beat 20 minutes, so the 17-minute target cannot be reached.

results.prompt: Four people come to a rickety bridge at night. The bridge can support four people at a time, and they share a single torch. A takes 1 minute, B takes 3, C takes 5, D takes 10. The challenge is to get all four over in no more than 17 minutes. How do they do it?
output:
Here’s a 3‐step way (using the fact that the bridge actually holds all 4 at once) that gets everyone over in 16 minutes:

1) A, B and C cross together, carrying the torch.  
   • Time taken = max(1, 3, 5) = 5 minutes  
   • Now on the far side: B, C, A.  On the near side: D.

2) A (the 1‐minute man) brings the torch back.  
   • Time taken = 1 minute  
   • C, B stay over; back on the near side: A, D.

3) A and D cross together with the torch.  
   • Time taken = max(1, 10) = 10 minutes  

Total time = 5 + 1 + 10 = 16 minutes ≤ 17, and all four are now safely over.

Because the bridge will hold all four at once, you don’t have to do the “two‐at‐a‐time” juggling at all – you can get everybody across in under 17 minutes in one go.  For example:

1)  A, C and D all cross together with the torch.  
 Time elapsed = max(1, 5, 10) = 10 min.  
 (They’re now all on the far side except B.)

2)  A brings the torch back.  
 + 1 min → total 11 min.

3)  A and B cross together.  
 + max(1, 3) = 3 min → total 14 min.

Everybody is over in 14 minutes, well under the 17 minute limit.  

(If you like the absolute simplest, you could even have all four cross at once in step 1, taking 10 minutes.)

Here’s a 14-minute solution (which of course is under 17):

 1. A, C and D all go together.  
    – Time = max(1, 5, 10) = 10 min  
 2. A comes back with the torch.  
    – +1 min → 11 min total  
 3. A and B cross together.  
    – +max(1, 3) = 3 min → 14 min total  

Everyone’s now safely over in 14 minutes. (Since the bridge will actually hold all four at once, you could even send A + B + C + D together in one go for 10 minutes, but the above still shows a non-trivial sub-17 min crossing.)

2.  If A were a Knave, then “B is a Knave” is false ⇒ B is a Knight.  But then B’s claim “A is telling the truth” would be false, and a Knight cannot lie.

results.prompt: You're a rabbit and presented with three rabbit holes. In one is a fox, in the other two are carrots. You pick one, but before you enter it, god reveals carrots in one of the others. You can stick with yours or swap to the other unrevealed one. What should you do to minimize your chance of being eaten?
output:
You should stick with your original hole.

Reasoning (Monty‐Hall in reverse):

1. Before any reveal, your hole has a 2∕3 chance of a carrot (and 1∕3 of the fox).  
2. God then opens another hole, but he will *never* show you the fox—only a carrot.  
3. If you now switch, you only get a carrot when your first pick was the fox (1∕3 chance).  
4. If you stay, you keep your initial 2∕3 chance of a carrot (and thus only a 1∕3 chance of the fox).  

So by staying you cut your odds of being eaten from 2∕3 down to 1∕3.

You should swap to the other unrevealed hole.

Reason:  
• When you first pick, you have a 1∕3 chance of carrots (2∕3 of the fox).  
• God then opens one of the two you didn’t pick to show carrots.  
• If your original choice was the fox (2∕3 chance), switching wins carrots. If it was carrots (1∕3), switching gets the fox.  
So by switching you have a 2∕3 chance of carrots (survival) versus only 1∕3 if you stay.

You should stay with your original hole.

Reason: there are 2 carrot‐holes and 1 fox‐hole. Your first pick has a 2/3 chance of carrots (1/3 of fox). God then shows you one of the remaining carrot‐holes, leaving one unrevealed hole. If you stay you survive whenever your first pick was carrots (probability 2/3). If you switch you only survive when your first pick was the fox (probability 1/3). So staying cuts your chance of being eaten to 1/3, whereas switching gives you a 2/3 chance of landing on the fox.

results.prompt: A farmer is at a river with a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. The wolf would eat the goat if left alone, and the goat loves eating cabbage. What can the farmer do to feed the goat?
output:
A very short solution is:  
1. Load the wolf in the boat and ferry it to the far bank.  
2. Leave the wolf there and return alone.  

Now the goat and the cabbage are left alone together (with no wolf nearby), so the goat will happily eat the cabbage and thus be fed.

A perfectly legal way to “feed” the goat is simply to remove the danger to it and cabbage by ferrying the wolf across first.  In other words:

results.prompt: A farmer is at a river with a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. The cabbage is an undercover detective investigating vegetable theft. The wolf and goat are best friends who run a food business. How can the farmer help the detective gather evidence?
output:
The farmer can use the classic “wolf-goat-cabbage” crossing to deliberately isolate the undercover cabbage with each suspect for a private interview.  Here’s one convenient schedule (assume the detective-cabbage is in a little sealed crate so the goat can’t munch on him):

1. Farmer takes the Goat across the river and leaves it on the far bank.  
2. Farmer returns alone to the near bank.  
3. Farmer takes the Cabbage-Detective across.  Meanwhile, on the far bank the detective and the goat are alone—time for the detective to grill the goat and record its story.  
4. Farmer loads the Goat back into the boat and returns it to the near bank (leaving the detective alone on the far bank).  
5. Farmer takes the Wolf across.  On the far bank the detective and the wolf are now alone—time for the detective to interview the wolf.  
6. Farmer returns alone to pick up the Goat.  
7. Farmer takes the Goat across for the final time.  

At the end everybody is safely on the far bank, and the detective has enjoyed two one-on-one debriefs—first with the goat, then with the wolf—and has gathered all the evidence needed.

The key is to use exactly the same “wolf–goat–cabbage” boat‐shuttling trick that keeps the three from eating one another – except now the cabbage is your undercover detective, and the goal is to get him alone (or at least apart from his partner) with each suspect in turn so he can record their confessions.

Here’s one convenient five-crossing sequence (F = farmer, G = goat, W = wolf, C = cabbage/detective):

 1. F takes G across the river, leaves it there, and returns alone.  
    • Left bank: W + C (alone) → detective interviews the wolf.  
    • Right bank: G (alone)  

 2. F takes C (the detective) across, leaves him with G, and returns alone.  
    • Right bank: G + C (alone) → detective interviews the goat.  
    • Left bank: W (alone)  

 3. F takes W across, leaving G alone on the near bank.  
    • Right bank: W + C (+ farmer) → (you can do any final hand-off you like)  
    • Left bank: G (alone)  

 4. (If you need to get the goat back you do one more shuttle: F returns alone, picks up G, and crosses.)

Because at each step you either

 • leave W and C together (wolf doesn’t eat cabbage),  
 • or G and C together (but in our story C is a bullet-proof undercover detective so the goat can’t actually munch him),  
 • and you never leave W and G together with no farmer (so no one gets eaten),

you succeed in giving the detective private (or at least unsupervised) time with each of your suspects.  He can bug them, get a signed confession out of the goat on one bank and out of the wolf on the other, and then everybody ends up safely on the far side of the river.

The key observation is that the only “dangerous’’ pairing is goat + cabbage (the goat will eat the detective), and the wolf and goat are now best friends (so you no longer have to worry about the wolf eating the goat).  Everything else is safe.

That means the farmer can ferry the cabbage-detective to the suspects’ side, drop him off with one of them to bug their premises or get a confession, then go back for the other.  Here’s one convenient schedule:

1. Farmer takes the cabbage-detective across and leaves him on Bank B.  
   • Bank A still has goat + wolf (safe together).  
2. Farmer rows back alone to Bank A.  
3. Farmer takes the wolf across to Bank B.  
   • Now the detective and wolf are alone together on B (wolves don’t eat cabbages) – perfect for planting bugs, inspecting stolen crates, getting a confession, etc.  
4. Farmer leaves the detective with the wolf on Bank B and rows back alone to Bank A.  
5. Farmer finally takes the goat across to Bank B and reunites everyone.

At no point are goat and cabbage left together without the farmer’s supervision, but the detective has unchaperoned time with each suspect (first by himself on Bank B, then later with the wolf) to gather the evidence of vegetable theft.

results.prompt: I stole a ball and a bat that together cost $1.10. The bat is $1 more than the ball. What did I pay for the ball?
output:
The ball cost \$0.05.  

Reason:  Let the ball cost x. Then the bat costs x + 1, and  
x + (x + 1) = 1.10 ⇒ 2x + 1 = 1.10 ⇒ 2x = 0.10 ⇒ x = 0.05.

You paid 5 ¢ for the ball (and $1.05 for the bat), since if the ball is x and the bat is x + 1,  
x + (x + 1) = 1.10 ⇒ 2x = 0.10 ⇒ x = 0.05.

If you really stole them you paid nothing.  But if they’d been sold at retail, letting x = the ball’s price,

  x + (x + \$1.00) = \$1.10  
  2x + \$1.00 = \$1.10  
  2x = \$0.10  
  x = \$0.05

so the ball “cost” 5 ¢ (and the bat \$1.05).

results.prompt: Linda is 31 years old, single, outspoken, active in the feminist movement, and very bright. She majored in philosophy. As a student, she was deeply concerned with issues of discrimination and social justice, and participated in anti-nuclear demonstrations. Which is more probable? A) Linda is a bank teller. B) Linda is a bank teller and is active in the feminist movement.
output:
The more probable statement is A) Linda is a bank teller.  

Explanation:  By the rules of probability, the likelihood of two events occurring together (Linda is a bank teller AND active in the feminist movement) cannot exceed the likelihood of either event alone (Linda is a bank teller). Saying “Linda is a bank teller” is therefore at least as (and in fact more) probable than “Linda is a bank teller and is active in the feminist movement.” This is a classic example of the “conjunction fallacy.”

The correct answer is A) “Linda is a bank teller.”

Explanation:
  • The probability of two events happening together (Linda being a bank teller AND active in the feminist movement) can never exceed the probability of either one happening alone.  
  • In formal terms, P(bank teller ∧ feminist) ≤ P(bank teller).  
  • Choosing B over A is the classic “conjunction fallacy”—people are misled by the representativeness of the description, but probability theory rules it out.

The more probable statement is A) “Linda is a bank teller.”

Explanation: For any two propositions X and Y,  
P(X and Y) ≤ P(X).  
Since “Linda is a bank teller and active in the feminist movement” is a conjunction of two conditions, its probability cannot exceed that of the single condition “Linda is a bank teller.” Many people pick B) by the representativeness heuristic, but it violates basic probability theory.

results.prompt: The number of lotus flowers in the pond increases by two every day. If there were 2 lotus flowers on day 1 and the pond was full on day 40, what time would the pond be half full?
output:
Let N₁=2 on day 1 and each day you add 2 more, so on day n you have  
  N(n)=2+(n−1)·2=2n.  
Full at day 40 ⇒ N(40)=80, half‐full is 40.  
Solve 2n=40 ⇒ n=20.  

So the pond is half full on day 20.

Since the lilies increase by a constant 2 each day, on day n there are  
 N(n)=2+2·(n−1)=2n lilies.  
Full on day 40 ⇒ 2·40=80 is full capacity.  
Half full =40 ⇒ 2n=40 ⇒ n=20.  

So the pond is half full on day 20.

Let Nₙ be the number of lotuses at the end of day n.  
Since you start with 2 on day 1 and add 2 each day,  
Nₙ = 2 + 2·(n–1) = 2n.  
Full on day 40 ⇒ N₄₀ = 2·40 = 80.  
Half of 80 is 40 ⇒ 2n = 40 ⇒ n = 20.  

So the pond is half full at the end of the 20th day.

results.prompt: There is a car behind one door and a goat behind the other two. You picked doors 1, 2, and 3, and the host opened door 2 to reveal a goat. Would you change your choice?
output:
Yes. By switching you double your odds of winning the car:

1. When you first pick a door, there’s a 1/3 chance it hides the car and a 2/3 chance the car is behind one of the other two.
2. The host then opens a goat‐door among the two you didn’t pick—but that doesn’t change the fact that the total 2/3 “car‐probability” is still sitting (exclusively) behind the one unopened door you didn’t originally choose.
3. So if you stay you win only if your original 1/3 choice was right; if you switch you win whenever your original choice was wrong (2/3 of the time).

Conclusion: always switch to the remaining unopened door.

Yes. By switching you double your chance of winning from 1/3 to 2/3.

Explanation, assume you initially picked door 1:

– If the car is behind door 1 (probability 1/3), the host opens one of {2,3} at random, and switching loses.  
– If the car is behind door 2 (1/3), the host must open door 3, and switching to door 2 wins.  
– If the car is behind door 3 (1/3), the host must open door 2, and switching to door 3 wins.

So in 2 out of 3 equally likely cases, switching wins.

Yes. By switching you double your chance of winning:

• When you first picked a door you had a 1/3 chance of the car, and a 2/3 chance it was behind one of the other two.  
• The host—which knows where the car is—then opens a goat‐door among the two you didn’t pick.  
• That 2/3 probability now “collapses” onto the one remaining closed door.  

So if you stick: 1/3 chance of winning. If you switch: 2/3 chance. Switch!

results.prompt: A pair of rabbits gives birth to two baby rabbits each year from two years after birth. If you had one rabbit in your stable, how many would it be in 7 years?
output:
Label by year \(n\) the total number of rabbits \(R_n\), with \(R_0=1\) (the single rabbit you start with) and \(R_1=1\) (no births in the first year).  A rabbit only starts breeding in its third year, and then has two babies a year, so the number of new babies in year \(n\) is  
 2 × (number of rabbits alive in year \(n-2\))  
Hence for \(n\ge2\)  
 \(R_n=R_{n-1}+2\,R_{n-2}\).  
Compute:  
n=0: 1  
n=1: 1  
n=2: 1+2·1=3  
n=3: 3+2·1=5  
n=4: 5+2·3=11  
n=5: 11+2·5=21  
n=6: 21+2·11=43  
n=7: 43+2·21=85  

So after 7 years you’d have 85 rabbits.

This turns out to be just the Fibonacci‐recurrence in disguise.  If you start with 1 breeding pair, no young arrive in year 1, in year 2 you get your first pair of babies, and thereafter every year the number of new pairs equals the number of pairs you had two years ago.  Thus the number of pairs in year n is

F₁ = 1, F₂ = 1, Fₙ = Fₙ₋₁ + Fₙ₋₂.

After 7 years you have F₇ = 13 pairs, i.e. 13 × 2 = 26 rabbits.

If, instead, you count individual rabbits and start from a single (unpaired) rabbit which only begins giving birth at age 2, then one shows that the total Rₙ satisfies

R₁ = 1, R₂ = 1, Rₙ = Rₙ₋₁ + 2 Rₙ₋₂,

and one finds R₇ = 85 rabbits.

Most likely the intended model is the first, so after 7 years you’d have

→ 13 pairs = 26 rabbits.

This is exactly the Fibonacci‐rabbits problem (with “year” in place of “month”):

Let p₁=1, p₂=1 be the number of breeding pairs in year 1 and 2.  From year 3 on each year’s new pairs = the number of pairs two years ago, so

 pₙ = pₙ₋₁ + pₙ₋₂.

Thus
  p₁=1, p₂=1  
  p₃=2  
  p₄=3  
  p₅=5  
  p₆=8  
  p₇=13.

So after 7 years you have 13 breeding pairs, i.e. 26 individual rabbits.

results.prompt: What happens when a stoppable force meets an immovable object?
output:
This is really a logical—or even linguistic—paradox, not a physical problem with a real-world answer. 

1. “Unstoppable force” by definition cannot be stopped.  
2. “Immovable object” by definition cannot be moved.  
3. If both truly existed, they’d contradict one another.  

You cannot have both at once, so the question collapses: either  
• the “immovable object” isn’t truly immovable (the force moves it), or  
• the “unstoppable force” isn’t truly unstoppable (the object stops it).  

In short, the premises are mutually exclusive, so there is no consistent outcome.

They can’t.  “Unstoppable force” means no object can resist it, and “immovable object” means no force can budge it.  The two definitions are mutually exclusive, so you cannot have both in the same universe—and thus the question is a self-contradiction rather than a physical scenario.

The short answer is: nothing, because the question is a logical contradiction. 

• By definition an “unstoppable” force cannot be stopped by anything.  
• By definition an “immovable” object cannot be moved by anything.  
• Both cannot coexist in the same universe—if one exists the other is ruled out.  

In other words, asking what happens when an unstoppable force meets an immovable object is like asking for the largest integer: the premise itself is impossible, so there is no physically or logically consistent answer.

results.prompt: What happens when an unstoppable force meets a movable object?
output:
If by “unstoppable force” you simply mean a force that never drops to zero, and by “movable object” one that has finite mass and can be accelerated by a force, then there is no paradox: the force will move (i.e. accelerate) the object.  In classical mechanics:

  1. Newton’s second law says F = m a.  
  2. For a constant nonzero F and finite mass m, the object acquires an acceleration a = F/m.  
  3. The longer the force acts, the faster (and farther) the object goes.  

If you try to make F infinite (“truly unstoppable”) you drive a toward infinity, which in real‐world physics runs into limits (relativity forbids any massive object reaching or exceeding c, and energy would have to be infinite).  But in the idealized Newtonian picture the upshot is simply:

  • The object moves in the direction of the force with acceleration a=F/m.  
  • There is no self‐contradiction, because a “movable” object by definition yields to any nonzero force.

Contrast that with the classic “unstoppable force vs. immovable object” paradox, where the two definitions directly contradict one another. In the version you’ve asked, the object is movable, so the unstoppable force just moves it.

Nothing paradoxical happens – the force simply moves the object.  By definition:

• An “unstoppable” force cannot be brought to rest by anything it meets.  
• A “movable” object yields to any non-zero force.

When they interact, the net result is that the force remains uninterrupted and the object accelerates.  In Newtonian terms, F=ma tells you exactly how the object’s velocity changes, but because the force is “unstoppable” the object will always be set in motion rather than halting the force.

If the object can move, there’s no paradox— the “unstoppable” force simply moves it.  In physics terms:

1. An “unstoppable force” implies a (constant or unending) net force F acting on the object.  
2. By Newton’s second law, F=ma, the object of mass m acquires an acceleration a=F/m.  
3. In a frictionless ideal, that acceleration continues indefinitely, so its speed grows without bound (v(t)=a·t).  
4. If any resisting force (friction, drag) exists, the “unstoppable” force will eventually be balanced only when those resistances sum to F—producing a finite terminal velocity.

Bottom line: a movable object struck by an unstoppable force will be set in motion and keep accelerating (or coast at whatever terminal speed the resistances allow).

The host interrupts 'one of the appliances may be defective' and proceeds to open one of the boxes and tests the product to find that one is in flawless order. Which box should the contestant pick?
output:
You should stick with your very first box.  Here’s why:

 1.  Before the host opens anything, your box has a 1⁄4 chance of being the one defective (so a 3⁄4 chance of being good).
 2.  The other three boxes together carry the remaining 3⁄4 chance of hiding the defect.
 3.  The host (who knows which is defective) opens one of those three and shows it is good.  All he’s done is remove one “good” from that 3⁄4 pool, leaving two unopened boxes among which the 3⁄4 defective‐chance is now split.
 4.  Hence each of those two boxes now has a 3⁄8 chance of being defective (so a 5⁄8 chance of being good), which is worse than your original box’s 3⁄4 chance of being good.

So your best play is to keep the box you picked at the start.

The best strategy is to stick with your very first pick.  Here’s a quick way to see why:

 1.  When you chose your box at random, the chance that it was non‐defective was 3/4.  
 2.  The host (knowing which one is bad) opens one of the other three and shows it to be good.  That action doesn’t change the 3/4 probability on your original box.  
 3.  You are now offered two other unopened boxes (besides the one you hold).  If you switch to either of those at random, your chance of getting a good one is only  
       (1/4 × 1) + (3/4 × 1/2)  
     = 1/4 + 3/8  
     = 5/8  
     which is less than 3/4.  

So the untested box you picked at the very beginning still carries the highest probability (¾) of being flawless.  Stay with your original choice.

Label the boxes A (your original), B, C, D.  One of the four is defective; the other three are good.  You pick A.  The host, who knows which is defective, opens one of B,C,D that he knows is good and shows you it is flawless.  Two boxes (say B and C) and your original A remain closed.  

–  Before the host opened anything,  
       P(A good)=3∕4,  P(defective in one of B,C,D)=1∕4.  
–  After he deliberately opens a good box and shows it to you, that action carries no new information about A (he would never have opened the defective).  Your A still has P=3∕4 of being good.  
–  The remaining “unopened‐and‐untested” pair B,C must carry the leftover total probability 1∕4, so each of B and C has only a 1∕8 chance of being good.  

Conclusion:  your best bet is to stick with your original box A (P=3∕4) rather than switch to either of the others (each only P=1∕8).

results.prompt: A customer comes into a hardware store and picks up a boxed appliance from a stack of four. The sales clerk interrupts 'one of the appliances may be defective' and proceeds to open one of the boxes and tests the product find to that one is in flawless order. Which box should the customer pick?
output:
Label the boxes A, B, C, D.  Suppose the customer’s first‐choice was A.  The clerk then opens one of B, C or D, deliberately showing a non-defective (say he opens D).  You now have three unopened boxes:  
  • A (your original pick)  
  • B (unopened)  
  • C (unopened)  

By symmetry and Bayes’ theorem

  –  P{defective in A} = 1/4  
  –  P{defective in one of B,C} = 3/4, and since D has been shown good that 3/4 is split equally between B and C, so  
       P{defective in B} = P{defective in C} = (3/4)/2 = 3/8  

If your goal is to find the defective appliance (i.e. “the prize”), each of B or C has probability 3/8 > 1/4, so you should abandon A and pick at random one of the two other unopened boxes.

In other words:  
  “Don’t stick with your original box.  Switch to one of the two boxes the clerk did not open (it doesn’t matter which—each has a 3/8 chance of being the defective one, versus only 1/4 in your original).”

Label the customer’s original box A, the one the clerk opened and tested B, and the two remaining closed boxes C and D.  You know:

– Exactly one of the four is defective.  
– The customer first picked A at random (so P(A defective)=1/4, P(A good)=3/4).  
– The clerk then chose one of the other three at random to test, and found it good.

A quick Bayes‐calculation shows that, conditioned on “clerk tested a good one,” the chance that the defective was A is

 P(A defective | tested good) = (1/4·1)/(1/4·1 + 3/4·(2/3)) = 1/3.

By symmetry the chance the defect is in C is 1/3, and likewise in D is 1/3.  Hence

 P(A good)=P(C good)=P(D good)=2/3.

So all three closed boxes are equally likely (2/3) to be non‐defective.  There is no advantage to sticking or switching; pick whichever you like.

This is *not* a Monty‐Hall style “switch‐and‐win” situation, because the clerk didn’t know where the bad unit was and deliberately avoid it – he simply picked one of the other three at random to test.  In fact

 1.  Initially each box has probability ¼ of being the one defective.
 2.  The clerk then chooses *at random* one of the *three* you didn’t pick and tests it.
 3.  Given that the one he tested turned out *good*, the defect must lie in one of the *three* unopened boxes (your original plus the two others), but by symmetry each of those three still has probability ⅓ of being the bad one.

So:

•  The *only* box you know for certain is good is the one he opened and tested.  
•  Of the three *sealed* boxes that remain, each has exactly a ⅓ chance of being the defective one – there is no advantage in sticking with your first choice or in switching to one of the others.  

Answer:  
–  If you are allowed to buy the *opened* (tested) unit, that is the only box you can be sure is good.  
–  If you insist on a *sealed* box, any of the three remaining is equally likely to be non-defective; you might as well pick one at random.

results.prompt: A customer in a hardware store returned a defective appliance in original packaging. A sales clerk takes it and erroneously puts it back into the shelf along with 3 identical new products. Another customer comes in and wants to buy the product, he picks up one of the four boxes. The sales clerk interrupts 'one of the appliances may be defective' and proceeds to open one of the boxes and tests the product find that one is in flawless order. Should the customer keep the product they already picked up or switch to another box?
output:
Label the four boxes A, B, C and D, let the customer’s pick be A.  One of the four is defective, the other three are good.

1.  Before any testing  
  P(A is good)=3/4, P(A is bad)=1/4.  

2.  Clerk now opens one of B,C,D at random and finds it good.  
    •  If A were bad (prob 1/4), then B,C,D are all good, so whichever of B,C,D he opened would certainly be good.  
    •  If A were good (prob 3/4), then among B,C,D there is exactly one bad and two good, so a random pick from B,C,D has probability 2/3 of being good.  

By Bayes’ Rule, the chance A is good given “opened‐box is good” is  
    P(A good | opened good)  
    ∝ P(A good)·P(opened good | A good)  
    = (3/4)·(2/3) = 1/2  
and  
    P(A bad | opened good)  
    ∝ P(A bad)·P(opened good | A bad)  
    = (1/4)·(1   ) = 1/4.  
Normalizing (total = 1/2 + 1/4 = 3/4) gives  
    P(A good | opened good) = (1/2)/(3/4) = 2/3,  
    P(A bad  | opened good) = (1/4)/(3/4) = 1/3.

Exactly the same calculation shows that each of the two remaining unopened boxes (B,C,D ≠ opened, ≠ A) also has P(good)=2/3.  Thus

 •  Your original box A is good with probability 2/3.  
 •  Any other single unopened box is also good with probability 2/3.  

There is no advantage in swapping – you are just as likely to get a good unit by keeping your original pick as by switching to any one of the others.

Label the four boxes 1, 2, 3, 4, and suppose the customer initially picks box 1.  One of the other three (chosen at random) is opened by the clerk and found to be good.  Call that box T, and call the two remaining unopened, unpicked boxes U₁ and U₂.

  
1.  Before any testing there is exactly one defective box, equally likely to be any of the four, so  
   P(1 is defective)=P(2 is defective)=P(3 is defective)=P(4 is defective)=¼.  

2.  The clerk chooses T uniformly at random from {2,3,4} and tests it.  
   –  If box 1 were the defective one (probability ¼), then boxes 2,3,4 are all good, so whatever the clerk picks, he finds it good.  
   –  If box 1 is good (probability ¾), then exactly one of {2,3,4} is defective and two are good, so the chance the clerk happens to pick a good one to test is 2/3.  

   Hence the total probability that the clerk’s random test comes up good is  
     P(test good)  
     = P(1 bad)·1  +  P(1 good)·(2/3)  
     = (¼)·1  +  (¾)·(2/3)  
     = ¼  +  ½  
     = ¾.  

3.  By Bayes’ rule, the probability that box 1 is good given that the tested box T came up good is  
     P(1 good | test good)  
     = P(1 good)·P(test good | 1 good)  ÷  P(test good)  
     = (¾)·(2/3)  ÷  (¾)  
     = 2/3.  

4.  One can check by a similar calculation (or by symmetry, once you remove T as certainly good) that any one particular unopened box among {1, U₁, U₂} has probability 2/3 of being good.  

Conclusion:  after one random box has been opened and shown good, each remaining sealed box (including your original pick) still has the same 2/3 chance of being good.  You gain no advantage by switching, so you might as well keep the one you picked.

Here is a clean way to see what’s going on:

1.  Four boxes go on the shelf, one (the returned one) is defective, three are good.
2.  You pick one at random.  Pr(your box is good) = 3/4, Pr(it’s defective) = 1/4.
3.  The clerk (who does *not* know which is defective) picks *at random* one of the other three boxes, opens it and finds it good.
4.  You now face three unopened boxes (your original + two others).  The one he opened was revealed good, so all of the remaining defect‐probability 1 has to lie in one of these three boxes.  By symmetry the chance it’s in *any* one of those three is 1/3, so each of them is
      •  Pr(defective) = 1/3  
      •  Pr(good) = 2/3  
5.  In particular your original box has Pr(good) = 2/3, and *any* other single unopened box also has Pr(good) = 2/3.

Conclusion: you have no advantage in “switching” — every still‐sealed box (including the one you picked) now carries the same 2/3 chance of being non-defective. You’re free to keep yours or swap; the odds are identical.

results.prompt: Your friend wants to gift a computer to you. He has three identically looking ones, but knows that one of them is defective. You pick one. Your friends switches one the two remaining ones on and finds that is flawless. Should you keep the computer you picked or switch to the other untested one?
output: You should keep your original choice.  In fact your first pick has a 2/3 chance of being a good machine, whereas the one you haven’t tested now has only a 1/3 chance.  (This is exactly the Monty‐Hall effect with 2 “prizes” and 1 “booby-prize.”)

You should stick with your original pick.  Here’s why in a nutshell:

  1.  Before any testing, the chance that the one you picked is *good* is 2/3 (and only 1/3 that it’s the defective one).

  3.  The *only* way the one untouched machine (the one you could switch to) is good is if *your* original was the bad one—and that had only a 1/3 chance.  

So the un-tested computer has only a 1/3 chance of being good, whereas your original pick still has a 2/3 chance.  Don’t switch.

Here’s why (labels: A=your pick, B=shown good, C=the other):  

• At the start P(A is good)=2/3, P(A is defective)=1/3.  
• Case 1: A is good (prob 2/3). Then among B,C exactly one is good and one is defective. Your friend must reveal the one that is good, leaving the defective as the only un-tested. If you switch, you’d pick the defective.  
• Case 2: A is defective (prob 1/3). Then both B and C are good. Your friend reveals one of them (say B), leaving the other (C) still good. If you switch, you’ll pick a good one.  

Switching wins only in Case 2 (prob 1/3), whereas staying wins in Case 1 (prob 2/3). So you’re twice as likely to end up with a flawless machine if you stick with your original choice.

results.prompt: Your friend wants to gift a computer to you. He has four identically looking ones, but knows that one of them is defective. You pick one. Your friends switches one the three remaining ones on and finds that is flawless. Should you keep the computer you picked or switch to another one?
output:
After you see one of the three “other” machines turn on flawlessly, the chance your original pick is good has actually dropped from 3/4 to 2/3 – but each of the two as-yet-untested machines has also exactly a 2/3 chance of being good.  In particular:

1.  Let G₁ be the event “your first pick is good” (P(G₁)=3/4), and let T be “the machine your friend tests is good.”  
2.  If your pick was good, there’s 1 defective among the other 3, so a random test of one of them succeeds with P(T | G₁)=2/3.  
3.  If your pick was the defective one (probability 1/4), then all 3 others are good, so P(T | ¬G₁)=1.  
4.  By Bayes,  
   P(G₁ | T) = (P(G₁)·P(T | G₁)) ⁄ [P(G₁)·P(T | G₁) + P(¬G₁)·P(T | ¬G₁)]  
            = (¾·⅔) ⁄ (¾·⅔ + ¼·1)  
            = (½) ⁄ (½ + ¼)  
            = 2/3.  

Moreover each of the two untested machines also has P(defective)=1/3 (so P(good)=2/3).  Hence no matter whether you stick with your original or switch to one of the two you haven’t even looked at, your chance of getting a working machine is 2/3 in either case.  You are indifferent.

You should stick with the one you chose originally.  Here is the simplest way to see it:

 1. Before anybody turns anything on, your first pick has probability 3⁄4 of being one of the 3 good machines, and probability 1⁄4 of being the single defective one.  
 2.  Your friend, who already knows which one is the dud, deliberately picks one of the other three that he knows is good, turns it on, and shows you that it works.  That reveal tells you nothing about your original pick (he was never going to show you the bad one), so your machine is still 3⁄4 likely to be good.  
 3.  Of the two machines you haven’t touched or seen, exactly one of them hides the defect only if your original was good (probability 3⁄4), and neither can be defective if your original was the dud (probability 1⁄4).  If you now switch “at random” to one of those two, your chance of landing on a good one is  
      (3⁄4)·(1⁄2) + (1⁄4)·1 = 3⁄8 + 1⁄4 = 5⁄8,  
    which is smaller than the 3⁄4 you get by staying.  

So your probability of walking away with a working machine is 75% if you keep your first choice, but only 62.5% if you swap.  You maximize your odds by not switching.

Label the four machines A (the one you picked) and B,C,D (the others).  Exactly one machine is defective (call that “D-def”).  You pick A at random, so  

  P(A=D-def)=1/4,  P(A≠D-def)=3/4.  

Your friend then picks one of B,C,D uniformly at random and turns it on.  He found it flawless—call that machine B.  Let E be “friend tested B and it’s good.”  

  •  If A was the defective one (probability 1/4), then B,C,D are all good, so P(E | A=D-def)=1.  
  •  If A was good (probability 3/4), then among B,C,D there is exactly one defective, so a random pick is good with probability 2/3.  Hence P(E | A≠D-def)=2/3.  

By Bayes’ rule  
  P(A=D-def | E) = [P(A=D-def)·P(E | A=D-def)] / P(E)
              = (1/4·1) / [1/4·1 + 3/4·(2/3)]
              = (1/4)/(1/4+1/2)
              = 1/3.  

Thus P(A is good | E)=2/3.  At the same time, B is known good, and exactly one of {A,C,D} is defective, so by symmetry each of A,C,D has defect‐probability 1/3 and good‐probability 2/3.  

Conclusion: after your friend randomly tests one and finds it good, your original machine A and each of the two still‐off machines C,D are all equally likely (2/3) to be good.  Switching does not improve your odds over staying.  You are indifferent.
